expanded_description: Multi-step inequalities combine all the concepts learned so far: distributing, combining like terms, variables on both sides, and the critical sign-flip rule. These problems require careful organization and attention to detail, but the same principles apply—isolate the variable using inverse operations, and remember to flip the inequality sign whenever multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

core_concept.principle: To solve a multi-step inequality: (1) Simplify each side by distributing and combining like terms. (2) Move variable terms to one side using addition/subtraction. (3) Move constant terms to the other side. (4) Multiply or divide to isolate the variable, flipping the inequality sign if multiplying or dividing by a negative number. (5) Graph the solution on a number line.
core_concept.explanation: Think of solving a multi-step inequality like untangling a complex knot—you work step by step, simplifying as you go. Each step should bring you closer to having the variable alone. The inequality sign is like a delicate thread—it stays the same unless you multiply or divide by a negative, at which point it must be flipped to keep the relationship true.

image.alt: Flowchart showing multi-step inequality solving process
image.caption: Figure 6.5.1: Solving multi-step inequalities.

sections.introduction: Before moving terms, simplify each side of the inequality by distributing and combining like terms.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.5.2: Simplifying each side of an inequality.

key_concept.definition: Just like with equations, start by simplifying each side of the inequality separately. Use the distributive property to remove parentheses, and combine like terms. This creates a simpler inequality to work with.
key_concept.context: Skipping this step can lead to errors. Always simplify before moving terms across the inequality sign.

worked_examples.title: Simplifying Inequalities
worked_examples.problem:
Simplify each inequality by distributing and combining like terms:
a) $3(x + 2) + 4 > 13$
b) $2(3x - 1) - 5 \leq 4x + 7$
c) $5 - 2(x + 3) \geq 3x - 4$
d) $\frac{1}{2}(4x + 6) - 3 < 2x + 1$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Simplify each side by distributing and combining like terms before moving variables.

sections.introduction: After simplifying, we often have variables on both sides. The next step is to collect them on one side.

key_concept.definition: To collect variables on one side, add or subtract the variable term from both sides. Choose the side that will keep the coefficient positive if possible, but either works—just be careful with signs.
key_concept.context: This step is identical to solving equations. The inequality sign remains the same during addition/subtraction.

worked_examples.title: Collecting Variable Terms

image.alt: Inequalities with variables on both sides
image.caption: Figure 6.5.8: Move variable terms to one side.

worked_examples.problem:
For each inequality, move variable terms to one side:
a) $6x - 7 \leq 4x + 7$
b) $-2x - 1 \geq 3x - 4$
c) $2x < 2x + 1$
d) $5x + 3 > 2x - 6$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Add or subtract variable terms to get all variables on one side.

image.caption: Figure 6.5.9: Variables on both sides summary.

sections.introduction: After variables are on one side, isolate the variable term by moving constants to the other side.

key_concept.definition: Add or subtract the constant term on the variable side to move it to the other side. This is just like two-step inequalities—addition/subtraction doesn't change the inequality sign.
key_concept.context: After this step, you'll have a one-step inequality in the form $ax \leq b$ or $\frac{x}{a} \leq b$.

worked_examples.title: Isolating the Variable Term
worked_examples.problem:
For each inequality, isolate the variable term by moving constants:
a) $2x - 7 \leq 7$
b) $-5x - 1 \geq -4$
c) $3x + 3 > -6$
d) $4x + 2 < 3x - 5$ (after moving variables, we get $x + 2 < -5$?) Let's do proper: $4x + 2 < 3x - 5$ → $x + 2 < -5$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Add or subtract constants to isolate the variable term.

sections.section_title: 6.5.4 Final Step: Solving for the Variable
sections.introduction: Finally, divide or multiply to isolate the variable, remembering to flip the sign if the coefficient is negative.

introduction_image.alt: Dividing or multiplying, checking for negative
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.5.14: Final step - solving for variable.

key_concept.definition: For inequalities in the form $ax \leq b$, divide both sides by $a$. If $a$ is positive, keep the sign. If $a$ is negative, divide and flip the inequality sign. For $\frac{x}{a} \leq b$, multiply by $a$, flipping if $a$ is negative.
key_concept.context: This is the same rule as in one-step and two-step inequalities. Don't forget to check the sign!

image.alt: Examples: 2x ≤ 14 → x ≤ 7; -5x ≥ -3 → x ≤ 3/5? Wait, flip: x ≤ 0.6? Actually -5x ≥ -3 → divide by -5, flip: x ≤ 0.6
image.caption: Figure 6.5.15: Final step examples.

worked_examples.title: Completing the Solution
worked_examples.problem:
Complete the solution for each inequality:
a) $2x \leq 14$
b) $-5x \geq -3$
c) $3x > -9$
d) $x < -7$ (already solved)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Divide or multiply, flipping if the number is negative.

sections.introduction: Now let's put all the steps together and solve complete multi-step inequalities.

key_concept.definition: A complete multi-step inequality solution involves: (1) Distributing and combining like terms, (2) Moving variable terms to one side, (3) Moving constants to the other side, (4) Dividing/multiplying to isolate the variable, flipping if necessary.
key_concept.context: These problems combine all previous skills. Work systematically and check each step.

image.alt: Several worked examples with all steps
image.caption: Figure 6.5.19: Complete examples.

worked_examples.title: Solving Multi-Step Inequalities
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each inequality and graph the solution:
a) $2(x + 3) - 5 > 4x + 1$
b) $3(2x - 1) + 2 \leq 5x - 4$
c) $4 - 3(x + 2) \geq 2x - 8$
d) $\frac{1}{2}(6x + 4) - 3 < 2x + 5$

step_by_step.calculation: Subtract $2x$: $1 > 2x + 1$ → subtract 1: $0 > 2x$ → divide by 2: $0 > x$ or $x < 0$

image.alt: Number line: open circle at 0, shaded left
image.caption: Figure 6.5.21: x < 0.

image.alt: Number line: closed circle at -3, shaded left
image.caption: Figure 6.5.22: x ≤ -3.

step_by_step.calculation: Add $3x$: $-2 \geq 5x - 8$ → add 8: $6 \geq 5x$ → divide by 5: $\frac{6}{5} \geq x$ or $x \leq 1.2$

image.alt: Number line: closed circle at 1.2, shaded left
image.caption: Figure 6.5.23: x ≤ 1.2.

image.alt: Number line: open circle at 6, shaded left
image.caption: Figure 6.5.24: x < 6.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Work through each step systematically: distribute, combine, move variables, move constants, divide.

worked_examples.title: Inequality with Special Result

image.alt: Inequality that simplifies to a statement
image.caption: Figure 6.5.25: Solve and interpret.

step_by_step.explanation: Since $1 > 1$ is never true, there is no solution.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Sometimes inequalities lead to false statements, meaning no values satisfy the inequality.

process_flow.description: Distribute and combine like terms on each side separately.
process_flow.mechanism: Use distributive property: $a(b + c) = ab + ac$. Combine constant terms and variable terms.

process_flow.description: Add or subtract variable terms to get all variables on one side.
process_flow.mechanism: Choose the side that will keep coefficients positive if possible.
process_flow.result: Variables on one side, constants on the other.

image.alt: Moving variable terms to one side
image.caption: Figure 6.5.27: Step 2 - Collect variable terms.

process_flow.description: Add or subtract constants to get the variable term alone.
process_flow.mechanism: Move constants to the other side using addition/subtraction.

process_flow.description: Divide or multiply to isolate the variable.
process_flow.mechanism: If dividing/multiplying by a negative, flip the inequality sign.

process_flow.description: Represent the solution on a number line.
process_flow.mechanism: Open circle for < or >, closed for ≤ or ≥. Shade in direction of inequality.

image.alt: Summary of complete multi-step solving process
image.caption: Figure 6.5.31: Multi-step solving summary.

sections.introduction: Multi-step inequalities often include fractions or decimals. The same principles apply, but we may want to clear fractions first.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.5.32: Working with fractions and decimals.

key_concept.definition: When inequalities contain fractions, multiply both sides by the least common denominator (LCD) to clear them. This creates an equivalent inequality with integer coefficients. Be careful—if you multiply by a negative number, you must flip the sign.
key_concept.context: Clearing fractions often makes the inequality easier to solve. Decimals can be cleared by multiplying by an appropriate power of 10.

worked_examples.title: Inequalities with Fractions
worked_examples.concept_applied: Clear fractions by multiplying by the LCD, then solve as usual.

worked_examples.title: Inequalities with Decimals
worked_examples.concept_applied: Decimals can be solved directly or cleared by multiplying by powers of 10.

image.alt: Summary of solving inequalities with fractions and decimals
image.caption: Figure 6.5.36: Fractions and decimals summary.

sections.introduction: Real-world situations often lead to multi-step inequalities, especially when multiple factors are involved.

introduction_image.alt: Real-world scenarios: business, science, everyday life
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.5.37: Real-world multi-step inequalities.

key_concept.definition: Real-world problems involving multiple conditions, rates, and constraints often require multi-step inequalities. Examples include comparing costs with discounts, determining when one investment outperforms another, or finding ranges that satisfy multiple requirements.
key_concept.context: These problems develop critical thinking and show the practical value of inequality solving.

image.alt: Examples: cell phone plans with taxes, temperature with wind chill, profit with costs
image.caption: Figure 6.5.38: Real-world examples.

worked_examples.title: Cell Phone Plan with Tax
worked_examples.problem: Plan A costs $\$45$ per month plus $\$0.10$ per minute. Plan B costs $\$60$ per month plus $\$0.05$ per minute. There is also a $5\%$ tax on the total monthly bill. For what number of minutes is Plan A cheaper after tax?
worked_examples.final_answer: Plan A is cheaper for less than 300 minutes after tax.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world problems may involve multiple steps like applying tax before comparison.

worked_examples.title: Temperature with Wind Chill

image.caption: Figure 6.5.40: Temperature with wind chill factor.

worked_examples.problem: The wind chill temperature $W$ in degrees Fahrenheit is given by $W = 35.74 + 0.6215T - 35.75v^{0.16} + 0.4275Tv^{0.16}$, where $T$ is the air temperature and $v$ is wind speed. For a fixed wind speed of 20 mph, this simplifies to $W = 0.6215T + 22.04$. If the wind chill must be above $-10°F$, what air temperatures are acceptable?
worked_examples.final_answer: Air temperature must be greater than about $-51.6°F$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Scientific formulas can lead to inequalities that need solving.

image.caption: Figure 6.5.41: Real-world applications summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to solve a variety of multi-step inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each inequality and graph the solution:
1) $3(x - 2) + 5 > 2x + 1$
2) $4 - 2(3x + 1) \leq 5x - 3$
3) $\frac{2}{3}x - \frac{1}{2} \geq \frac{5}{6}$
4) $0.4x + 1.2 < 0.6x - 0.8$
5) $2(x + 3) - 4(x - 1) > 3x + 5$
6) Real-world: You have $\$200$ in savings and add $\$25$ per week. Your friend has $\$300$ in savings and adds $\$15$ per week. After how many weeks will you have more than your friend?

image.alt: Number line: open circle at 2, shaded right
image.caption: Figure 6.5.48: x > 2.

step_by_step.calculation: Add $6x$: $2 \leq 11x - 3$ → add 3: $5 \leq 11x$ → divide by 11: $\frac{5}{11} \leq x$ or $x \geq \frac{5}{11}$

image.alt: Number line: closed circle at 5/11, shaded right
image.caption: Figure 6.5.49: x ≥ 5/11.

image.alt: Number line: closed circle at 2, shaded right
image.caption: Figure 6.5.50: x ≥ 2.

image.alt: Number line: open circle at 10, shaded right
image.caption: Figure 6.5.51: x > 10.

step_by_step.calculation: Add $2x$: $10 > 5x + 5$ → subtract 5: $5 > 5x$ → divide by 5: $1 > x$ or $x < 1$

image.alt: Number line: open circle at 1, shaded left
image.caption: Figure 6.5.52: x < 1.

summary: Solving multi-step inequalities requires combining all previously learned skills in a systematic way. Begin by simplifying each side using the distributive property and combining like terms. Next, collect variable terms on one side using addition or subtraction—the inequality sign remains unchanged during these steps. Then isolate the variable term by moving constants to the other side. Finally, multiply or divide to solve for the variable, remembering to flip the inequality sign if you multiply or divide by a negative number. When fractions are present, multiply both sides by the least common denominator to clear them; be aware that if you multiply by a negative number, you must flip the sign. Decimals can be handled directly or cleared by multiplying by powers of 10. Some inequalities may simplify to statements that are always true (all real numbers) or always false (no solution). Real-world applications include comparing costs with taxes, temperature formulas, and savings comparisons. Mastering multi-step inequalities prepares students for more advanced topics in algebra and for modeling complex real-world constraints.
